**Sir Edmund Percival Hillary**
[KG](/wiki/Knight_Companion_of_The_Most_Noble_Order_of_the_Garter "Knight
Companion of The Most Noble Order of the Garter")
[ONZ](/wiki/Member_of_The_Order_of_New_Zealand "Member of The Order of New
Zealand")
[KBE](/wiki/Knight_Commander_of_The_Most_Excellent_Order_of_the_British_Empire
"Knight Commander of The Most Excellent Order of the British Empire")
[OSN](/wiki/Order_of_the_Star_of_Nepal "Order of the Star of Nepal") (20 July
1919 – 11 January 2008) was a New Zealand [mountaineer](/wiki/Mountaineering
"Mountaineering"), explorer, and [philanthropist](/wiki/Philanthropy
"Philanthropy"). On 29 May 1953, Hillary and [Nepalese](/wiki/Nepal "Nepal")
[Sherpa](/wiki/Sherpa_people "Sherpa people") mountaineer [Tenzing
Norgay](/wiki/Tenzing_Norgay "Tenzing Norgay") became the [first
climbers](/wiki/Timeline_of_Mount_Everest_expeditions "Timeline of Mount
Everest expeditions") confirmed to have reached the summit of [Mount
Everest](/wiki/Mount_Everest "Mount Everest"). They were part of the [ninth
British expedition to Everest](/wiki/1953_British_Mount_Everest_expedition
"1953 British Mount Everest expedition"), led by [John
Hunt](/wiki/John_Hunt,_Baron_Hunt "John Hunt, Baron Hunt").

Hillary became interested in mountaineering while in secondary school. He made
his first major climb in 1939, reaching the summit of [Mount
Ollivier](/wiki/Mount_Ollivier "Mount Ollivier"). He served in the [Royal New
Zealand Air Force](/wiki/Royal_New_Zealand_Air_Force "Royal New Zealand Air
Force") as a [navigator](/wiki/Navigator "Navigator") during [World War
II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"). Prior to the Everest expedition,
Hillary had been part of the [British reconnaissance
expedition](/wiki/1951_British_Mount_Everest_reconnaissance_expedition "1951
British Mount Everest reconnaissance expedition") to the mountain in 1951 as
well as an unsuccessful attempt to climb [Cho Oyu](/wiki/Cho_Oyu "Cho Oyu") in
1952. As part of the [Commonwealth Trans-Antarctic
Expedition](/wiki/Commonwealth_Trans-Antarctic_Expedition "Commonwealth Trans-
Antarctic Expedition") he reached the [South Pole](/wiki/South_Pole "South
Pole") overland in 1958. He subsequently reached the [North
Pole](/wiki/North_Pole "North Pole"), making him the first person to reach
both poles and summit Everest.

Following his ascent of Everest, Hillary devoted himself to assisting the
Sherpa people of Nepal through the [Himalayan Trust](/wiki/Himalayan_Trust
"Himalayan Trust"), which he established. His efforts are credited with the
construction of many schools and hospitals in Nepal. From 1985 to 1988 he
served as New Zealand's [High Commissioner to India and
Bangladesh](/wiki/List_of_High_Commissioners_of_New_Zealand_to_India "List of
High Commissioners of New Zealand to India") and concurrently as Ambassador to
Nepal. Hillary had numerous honours conferred upon him, including the [Order
of the Garter](/wiki/Order_of_the_Garter "Order of the Garter") in 1995. Upon
his death in 2008, he was given a [state funeral](/wiki/State_funeral "State
funeral") in New Zealand.

## Early life

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Gertrude_Clark%2C_mother_of_Edmund_Hillary%2C_1909.jpg/170px-
Gertrude_Clark%2C_mother_of_Edmund_Hillary%2C_1909.jpg)](/wiki/File:Gertrude_Clark,_mother_of_Edmund_Hillary,_1909.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Gertrude_Clark,_mother_of_Edmund_Hillary,_1909.jpg "Enlarge")

Hillary's mother Gertrude Clark, 1909

Hillary was born to Percival Augustus and Gertrude (née Clark) Hillary in
[Auckland](/wiki/Auckland "Auckland"), New Zealand, on 20 July 1919.[1][2] His
family moved to [Tuakau](/wiki/Tuakau "Tuakau"), south of Auckland, in 1920,
after his father, who served at [Gallipoli](/wiki/Gallipoli_Campaign
"Gallipoli Campaign") with the 15th (North Auckland) Regiment, was allocated
land there.[2] His grandparents had emigrated from [Yorkshire](/wiki/Yorkshire
"Yorkshire") to northern [Wairoa](/wiki/Wairoa_River_\(Northland\) "Wairoa
River \(Northland\)") in the mid-19th century.[3]

Hillary was educated at Tuakau Primary School and then [Auckland Grammar
School](/wiki/Auckland_Grammar_School "Auckland Grammar School").[2] He
finished primary school two years early and at high school achieved average
marks.[4] He was initially smaller than his peers and shy, but gained
confidence after taking up [boxing](/wiki/Boxing "Boxing"). He became
interested in climbing when he was 16 following a school trip to [Mount
Ruapehu](/wiki/Mount_Ruapehu "Mount Ruapehu"), after which he showed more
interest in [tramping](/wiki/Tramping "Tramping") than in studying and said he
"wanted to see the world".[5][6]

He studied mathematics and science at [Auckland University
College](/wiki/Auckland_University_College "Auckland University College") and
in 1939 completed his first major climb, reaching the summit of [Mount
Ollivier](/wiki/Mount_Ollivier "Mount Ollivier"), near [Aoraki / Mount
Cook](/wiki/Aoraki_/_Mount_Cook "Aoraki / Mount Cook") in the [Southern
Alps](/wiki/Southern_Alps "Southern Alps").[2] He took up
[beekeeping](/wiki/Beekeeper "Beekeeper") with his brother,[1][7] which
occupied him in the summer while he concentrated on climbing in winter.[8] His
father was a beekeeper, and although Hillary's inclination was for climbing,
he became a professional beekeeper.[9][10] He joined the Radiant Living
Tramping Club, where a health philosophy developed by [Herbert
Sutcliffe](/wiki/Herbert_Sutcliffe_\(health_advocate\) "Herbert Sutcliffe
\(health advocate\)") was taught; tours with the club through the [Waitakere
Ranges](/wiki/Waitakere_Ranges "Waitakere Ranges") further developed his love
of the outdoors.[11]

## World War II

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Edmund_Hillary_at_Delta_Camp_near_Blenheim_during_WWII.jpg/170px-
Edmund_Hillary_at_Delta_Camp_near_Blenheim_during_WWII.jpg)](/wiki/File:Edmund_Hillary_at_Delta_Camp_near_Blenheim_during_WWII.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Edmund_Hillary_at_Delta_Camp_near_Blenheim_during_WWII.jpg
"Enlarge")

Hillary in [Royal New Zealand Air Force](/wiki/Royal_New_Zealand_Air_Force
"Royal New Zealand Air Force") uniform at Delta Camp, near [Blenheim, New
Zealand](/wiki/Blenheim,_New_Zealand "Blenheim, New Zealand"), during [World
War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II")

At the outbreak of [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"), Hillary
applied to join the [Royal New Zealand Air
Force](/wiki/Royal_New_Zealand_Air_Force "Royal New Zealand Air Force")
(RNZAF) but quickly withdrew the application, later writing that he was
"harassed by my [religious conscience](/wiki/Conscientious_objector
"Conscientious objector")".[12] In 1943, with the Japanese threat in the
Pacific and the arrival of
[conscription](/wiki/Compulsory_Military_Training_in_New_Zealand "Compulsory
Military Training in New Zealand"), he joined the RNZAF as a
[navigator](/wiki/Navigator "Navigator") in [No. 6 Squadron
RNZAF](/wiki/No._6_Squadron_RNZAF "No. 6 Squadron RNZAF") and later [No. 5
Squadron RNZAF](/wiki/No._5_Squadron_RNZAF "No. 5 Squadron RNZAF") on
[Catalina flying boats](/wiki/Consolidated_PBY_Catalina "Consolidated PBY
Catalina").[12][13] In 1945, he was sent to [Fiji](/wiki/Fiji "Fiji") and to
the [Solomon Islands](/wiki/Solomon_Islands "Solomon Islands"), where he was
badly burnt in an accident.[12]

## Expeditions

In January 1948, Hillary and others ascended the south ridge of [Aoraki /
Mount Cook](/wiki/Aoraki_/_Mount_Cook "Aoraki / Mount Cook"), New Zealand's
highest peak.[14] In 1951 he was part of a [British reconnaissance
expedition](/wiki/1951_British_Mount_Everest_reconnaissance_expedition "1951
British Mount Everest reconnaissance expedition") to Everest led by [Eric
Shipton](/wiki/Eric_Shipton "Eric Shipton"),[15] before joining the successful
British attempt of 1953. In 1952, Hillary and [George
Lowe](/wiki/George_Lowe_\(mountaineer\) "George Lowe \(mountaineer\)") were
part of the British team led by Shipton, that attempted [Cho
Oyu](/wiki/Cho_Oyu "Cho Oyu").[16] After that attempt failed due to the lack
of route from the Nepal side, Hillary and Lowe crossed the Nup La pass into
Tibet and reached the old Camp II, on the northern side, where all the
previous expeditions had camped.[17]

### 1953 Everest expedition

Main article: [1953 British Mount Everest
expedition](/wiki/1953_British_Mount_Everest_expedition "1953 British Mount
Everest expedition")

External audio
![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Nuvola_apps_arts.svg/16px-
Nuvola_apps_arts.svg.png) [Sir Edmund Hillary Scales the Heights of Literary
Society](http://www.wnyc.org/story/sir-edmund-hillary-scales-heights-literary-
society/), 1954, Hillary speaks 5:00–18:57, [WNYC](/wiki/WNYC "WNYC")[18]  
---  
  
In 1949, the long-standing climbing route to the summit of Everest was closed
by Chinese-controlled [Tibet](/wiki/Tibet "Tibet"). For the next several
years, [Nepal](/wiki/Nepal "Nepal") allowed only one or two expeditions per
year.[19] A Swiss expedition (in which Tenzing took part) attempted to reach
the summit in 1952, but was forced back by bad weather around 800 feet (240 m)
below the summit.[20] In 1952 Hillary learned that he and Lowe had been
invited by the [Joint Himalayan Committee](/wiki/Joint_Himalayan_Committee
"Joint Himalayan Committee") for the 1953 British attempt and immediately
accepted.[21]

Shipton was named as leader but was replaced by Hunt. Hillary was immediately
impressed by Hunt's energy and determination.[22] Hillary had intended to
climb with Lowe, but Hunt named two teams for the assault: [Tom
Bourdillon](/wiki/Tom_Bourdillon "Tom Bourdillon") and [Charles
Evans](/wiki/Charles_Evans_\(mountaineer\) "Charles Evans \(mountaineer\)");
and Hillary and Tenzing.[23] Hillary, therefore, made a concerted effort to
forge a working friendship with Tenzing.[22]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Tenzing_and_Hillary.jpg/220px-
Tenzing_and_Hillary.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tenzing_and_Hillary.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Tenzing_and_Hillary.jpg "Enlarge")

Tenzing and Hillary

The Hunt expedition totalled over 400 people, including 362
[porters](/wiki/Porter_\(carrier\) "Porter \(carrier\)"), 20
[Sherpa](/wiki/Sherpa_people "Sherpa people") guides, and 10,000 pounds (4,500
kg) of baggage.[24][25] Lowe supervised the preparation of the [Lhotse
Face](/wiki/Lhotse "Lhotse"), a huge and steep ice face, for climbing. Hillary
forged a route through the treacherous [Khumbu Icefall](/wiki/Khumbu_Icefall
"Khumbu Icefall").[26][27]

The expedition set up [base camp](/wiki/Base_camp "Base camp") in March 1953
and, working slowly, set up its final camp at the [South Col](/wiki/South_Col
"South Col") at 25,900 feet (7,890 m). On 26 May, Bourdillon and Evans
attempted the climb but turned back when Evans' [oxygen
system](/wiki/Oxygen_system "Oxygen system") failed. The pair had reached the
South Summit, coming within 300 vertical feet (91 m) of the summit.[25][28]
Hunt then directed Hillary and Tenzing to attempt the summit.[28]

Snow and wind delayed them at the South Col for two days. They set out on 28
May with the support of Lowe, [Alfred Gregory](/wiki/Alfred_Gregory "Alfred
Gregory"), and Ang Nyima.[29] The two pitched a tent at 27,900 feet (8,500 m)
on 28 May, while their support group returned down the mountain.[30] On the
following morning Hillary discovered that his boots had frozen solid outside
the tent. He spent two hours warming them over a stove before he and Tenzing,
wearing 30-pound (14 kg) packs, attempted the final ascent.[31] The final
obstacle was the 40-foot (12 m) rock face now called "[Hillary
Step](/wiki/Hillary_Step "Hillary Step")"; Hillary later wrote:

> I noticed a crack between the rock and the snow sticking to the East Face. I
> crawled inside and wriggled and jammed my way to the top ... Tenzing slowly
> joined me and we moved on. I chopped steps over bump after bump, wondering a
> little desperately where the top could be. Then I saw the ridge ahead
> dropped away to the north and above me on the right was a rounded snow dome.
> A few more whacks with my ice-axe and Tenzing and I stood on top of
> Everest.[32]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Edmund_Hillary_and_Tenzing_Norgay.jpg/220px-
Edmund_Hillary_and_Tenzing_Norgay.jpg)](/wiki/File:Edmund_Hillary_and_Tenzing_Norgay.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Edmund_Hillary_and_Tenzing_Norgay.jpg "Enlarge")

Hillary and Tenzing on return from the Everest's summit

Tenzing later wrote that Hillary took the first step onto the summit and he
followed. They reached Everest's 29,028 ft (8,848 m) summit – the highest
point on earth – at 11:30 am.[1][33]

They spent about 15 minutes at the summit. Hillary took a photo of Tenzing
posing with his ice-axe, but there is no photo of Hillary. BBC News attributed
this to Tenzing's having never used a camera;[34][35] Tenzing's autobiography
says that Hillary simply declined to have his picture taken. They also took
photos looking down the mountain.[35]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Sir_Edmund_Hillary%2C_Sir_Willoughby_Norrie%2C_and_George_Lowe_at_Government_House%2C_Wellington%2C_1953.jpg/220px-
Sir_Edmund_Hillary%2C_Sir_Willoughby_Norrie%2C_and_George_Lowe_at_Government_House%2C_Wellington%2C_1953.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sir_Edmund_Hillary,_Sir_Willoughby_Norrie,_and_George_Lowe_at_Government_House,_Wellington,_1953.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Sir_Edmund_Hillary,_Sir_Willoughby_Norrie,_and_George_Lowe_at_Government_House,_Wellington,_1953.jpg
"Enlarge")

Hillary (left) and [George Lowe](/wiki/George_Lowe_\(mountaineer\) "George
Lowe \(mountaineer\)") (right) with Governor-General [Sir Willoughby
Norrie](/wiki/Sir_Willoughby_Norrie "Sir Willoughby Norrie") at [Government
House, Wellington](/wiki/Government_House,_Wellington "Government House,
Wellington"), 20 August 1953

Tenzing left chocolates at the summit as an offering, and Hillary left a cross
given him by John Hunt.[36] Their descent was complicated by drifting snow
which had covered their tracks. The first person they met was Lowe; Hillary
said, "Well, George, we knocked the bastard off."[6]

They returned to [Kathmandu](/wiki/Kathmandu "Kathmandu") a few days later and
learned that Hillary had already been appointed a [Knight Commander of the
Order of the British Empire](/wiki/Order_of_British_Empire "Order of British
Empire") and Hunt a [Knight Bachelor](/wiki/Knight_Bachelor "Knight
Bachelor").[37] News reached Britain on the day of [Queen Elizabeth II's
coronation](/wiki/Coronation_of_Queen_Elizabeth_II "Coronation of Queen
Elizabeth II"), and the press called it a coronation gift.[38] The 37 members
of the party later received the [Queen Elizabeth II Coronation
Medal](/wiki/Queen_Elizabeth_II_Coronation_Medal "Queen Elizabeth II
Coronation Medal") with mount everest expedition engraved along the rim.[39]
In addition to the [knighting](/wiki/Knight "Knight") of Hillary and Hunt,
Tenzing – ineligible for knighthood as a Nepalese citizen – received the
[George Medal](/wiki/George_Medal "George Medal").[40][41][42] Tenzing also
received the [Star of Nepal](/wiki/Order_of_the_Star_of_Nepal "Order of the
Star of Nepal") from [King Tribhuvan](/wiki/King_Tribhuvan "King
Tribhuvan").[43]

### After Everest

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Sir_Edmund_Hillary_in_the_cockpit_of_the_Trans-
Antarctic_Expedition%27s_aeroplane%2C_Rongotai%2C_Wellington%2C_1956.jpg/170px-
Sir_Edmund_Hillary_in_the_cockpit_of_the_Trans-
Antarctic_Expedition%27s_aeroplane%2C_Rongotai%2C_Wellington%2C_1956.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sir_Edmund_Hillary_in_the_cockpit_of_the_Trans-
Antarctic_Expedition%27s_aeroplane,_Rongotai,_Wellington,_1956.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Sir_Edmund_Hillary_in_the_cockpit_of_the_Trans-
Antarctic_Expedition%27s_aeroplane,_Rongotai,_Wellington,_1956.jpg "Enlarge")

In the cockpit of the [Commonwealth Trans-Antarctic
Expedition](/wiki/Commonwealth_Trans-Antarctic_Expedition "Commonwealth Trans-
Antarctic Expedition")'s [DHC-2](/wiki/De_Havilland_Canada_DHC-2_Beaver "De
Havilland Canada DHC-2 Beaver"), 1956

Hillary climbed ten other peaks in the [Himalayas](/wiki/Himalayas
"Himalayas") on further visits in 1956, 1960–1961, and 1963–1965. He also
reached the [South Pole](/wiki/South_Pole "South Pole") as part of the
[Commonwealth Trans-Antarctic Expedition](/wiki/Commonwealth_Trans-
Antarctic_Expedition "Commonwealth Trans-Antarctic Expedition"), for which he
led the New Zealand section, on 4 January 1958. His party was the first to
reach the Pole overland since [Amundsen](/wiki/Roald_Amundsen "Roald
Amundsen") in 1911 and [Scott](/wiki/Robert_Falcon_Scott "Robert Falcon
Scott") in 1912, and the first ever to do so using motor vehicles.[44]

In 1960 Hillary organized an expedition to search for the fabled [abominable
snowman](/wiki/Yeti "Yeti").[45] Hillary was with the expedition for five
months, although it lasted for ten.[46] No evidence of Yetis was found,
instead footprints and tracks were proven to be from other causes. During the
expedition, Hillary travelled to remote temples which contained "Yeti scalps";
however after bringing back three relics, two were shown to be from bears and
one from a goat antelope.[47][48] Hillary said after the expedition: "The yeti
is not a strange, superhuman creature as has been imagined. We have found
rational explanations for most yeti phenomena".[49]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Edmund-
Hillary.web.jpg/170px-Edmund-Hillary.web.jpg)](/wiki/File:Edmund-
Hillary.web.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Edmund-Hillary.web.jpg "Enlarge")

Hillary in 1957 after ac­com­pa­nying the first plane to land at the [Marble
Point](/wiki/Marble_Point "Marble Point") ground air strip, Antarctica

In 1962 he was a guest on the television game show _[What's My
Line?](/wiki/What%27s_My_Line%3F "What's My Line?")_; he stumped the panel,
comprising [Dorothy Kilgallen](/wiki/Dorothy_Kilgallen "Dorothy Kilgallen"),
[Arlene Francis](/wiki/Arlene_Francis "Arlene Francis"), [Bennett
Cerf](/wiki/Bennett_Cerf "Bennett Cerf"), and [Merv
Griffin](/wiki/Merv_Griffin "Merv Griffin").[50] In 1977, he led a
[jetboat](/wiki/Jetboat "Jetboat") expedition, titled "Ocean to Sky", from the
mouth of the [Ganges River](/wiki/Ganges_River "Ganges River") to its
source.[51] From 1977 to 1979 he commentated aboard Antarctic sightseeing
flights operated by [Air New Zealand](/wiki/Air_New_Zealand "Air New
Zealand").[52] In 1985, he accompanied [Neil Armstrong](/wiki/Neil_Armstrong
"Neil Armstrong") in a small twin-engined ski plane over the Arctic Ocean and
landed at the [North Pole](/wiki/North_Pole "North Pole"). Hillary thus became
the first man to stand at both poles and on the summit of
Everest.[53][54][55][56] This accomplishment inspired generations of explorers
to compete over what later was defined as [Three Poles
Challenge](/wiki/Three_Poles_Challenge "Three Poles Challenge"). In January
2007, Hillary travelled to Antarctica as part of a delegation commemorating
the 50th anniversary of the founding of [Scott Base](/wiki/Scott_Base "Scott
Base").[57][58][59]

## Public recognition

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/7/7c/Nz5d.jpg/220px-
Nz5d.jpg)](/wiki/File:Nz5d.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Nz5d.jpg "Enlarge")

Hillary on the [New Zealand five-dollar note](/wiki/New_Zealand_dollar "New
Zealand dollar")

On 6 June 1953 Hillary was appointed [Knight Commander of the Order of the
British Empire](/wiki/Knight_Commander_of_the_Order_of_the_British_Empire
"Knight Commander of the Order of the British Empire") and received the [Queen
Elizabeth II Coronation Medal](/wiki/Queen_Elizabeth_II_Coronation_Medal
"Queen Elizabeth II Coronation Medal") the same year.[60] On 6 February 1987,
he was the fourth appointee to the [Order of New
Zealand](/wiki/Order_of_New_Zealand "Order of New Zealand").[61] He was also
awarded the [Polar Medal](/wiki/Polar_Medal "Polar Medal") in 1958 for his
part in the Commonwealth Trans-Antarctic Expedition,[62][63] the [Order of
Gorkha Dakshina Bahu, 1st Class](/wiki/Order_of_Gorkha_Dakshina_Bahu "Order of
Gorkha Dakshina Bahu") of the [Kingdom of Nepal](/wiki/Nepal "Nepal") in 1953,
and the Coronation Medal in 1975.[64] On 22 April 1995 Hillary was appointed
[Knight Companion of The Most Noble Order of the
Garter](/wiki/Knight_Companion_of_The_Most_Noble_Order_of_the_Garter "Knight
Companion of The Most Noble Order of the Garter").[65][66] On 17 June 2004
Hillary was awarded [Commander's Cross of the Order of Merit of the Republic
of Poland](/wiki/Order_of_Merit_of_the_Republic_of_Poland "Order of Merit of
the Republic of Poland").[67] The Government of India conferred on him its
second highest civilian award, the [Padma Vibhushan](/wiki/Padma_Vibhushan
"Padma Vibhushan"), posthumously, in 2008.[68]

To mark the 50th anniversary of the first successful ascent of Everest, the
[Nepalese government](/wiki/Nepalese_government "Nepalese government")
conferred honorary citizenship upon Hillary at a special [Golden
Jubilee](/wiki/Golden_Jubilee "Golden Jubilee") celebration in
[Kathmandu](/wiki/Kathmandu "Kathmandu"), Nepal. He was the first foreign
national to receive that honour.[69][10]

Since 1992, New Zealand's $5 note has featured Hillary's portrait, making him
the only living person not a current head of state ever to appear on a New
Zealand banknote. In giving his permission, Hillary insisted that [Aoraki /
Mount Cook](/wiki/Aoraki_/_Mount_Cook "Aoraki / Mount Cook") rather than Mount
Everest be used as the backdrop.[70][71]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Hillary_statue_and_Mount_Cook.jpg/220px-
Hillary_statue_and_Mount_Cook.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hillary_statue_and_Mount_Cook.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Hillary_statue_and_Mount_Cook.jpg "Enlarge")

Statue of Hillary gazing towards [Aoraki / Mount
Cook](/wiki/Aoraki_/_Mount_Cook "Aoraki / Mount Cook"), one of his favourite
peaks[72]

Annual _[Reader's Digest](/wiki/Reader%27s_Digest "Reader's Digest")_ polls
from 2005 to 2007 named Hillary as "New Zealand's most trusted
individual".[73][74]

Hillary's favoured New Zealand charity was the [Sir Edmund Hillary Outdoor
Pursuits Centre](/wiki/Sir_Edmund_Hillary_Outdoor_Pursuits_Centre "Sir Edmund
Hillary Outdoor Pursuits Centre"), of which he was patron for 35 years.[75] He
was particularly keen on how this organisation introduced young New Zealanders
to the outdoors in a very similar way to his first experience of a school trip
to Mt Ruapehu at the age of 16. A 2.3-metre (7.5 ft) bronze statue of Hillary
was erected outside [The Hermitage
Hotel](/wiki/The_Hermitage_Hotel,_Mount_Cook_Village "The Hermitage Hotel,
Mount Cook Village") at [Mount Cook Village](/wiki/Mount_Cook_Village "Mount
Cook Village"); it was unveiled by Hillary himself in 2003.[76] Various
streets, institutions and organisations around New Zealand and abroad are
named after him – for example, the [Sir Edmund Hillary
Collegiate](/wiki/Sir_Edmund_Hillary_Collegiate "Sir Edmund Hillary
Collegiate") in [Otara](/wiki/Otara "Otara"), which was established by Hillary
in 2001.[77]

Two Antarctic features are named after Hillary. The [Hillary
Coast](/wiki/Hillary_Coast "Hillary Coast") is a section of coastline south of
Ross Island and north of the Shackleton Coast.[78] The Hillary Canyon, an
undersea feature in the Ross Sea, appears on the [General Bathymetric Chart of
the Oceans](/wiki/General_Bathymetric_Chart_of_the_Oceans "General Bathymetric
Chart of the Oceans"), published by the [International Hydrographic
Organization](/wiki/International_Hydrographic_Organization "International
Hydrographic Organization").[79]

## Personal life

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Sir_Edmund_and_Lady_Louise_Hillary_with_their_son_Peter%2C_1955.jpg/220px-
Sir_Edmund_and_Lady_Louise_Hillary_with_their_son_Peter%2C_1955.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sir_Edmund_and_Lady_Louise_Hillary_with_their_son_Peter,_1955.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Sir_Edmund_and_Lady_Louise_Hillary_with_their_son_Peter,_1955.jpg
"Enlarge")

Hillary, with first wife, Louise, and son, [Peter](/wiki/Peter_Hillary "Peter
Hillary"), 1955

Hillary married Louise Mary Rose on 3 September 1953, soon after the ascent of
Everest; he admitted he was terrified of proposing to her and relied on her
mother to propose on his behalf.[7][8][80] They had three children: Peter
(born 1954), Sarah (born 1955) and Belinda (1959–1975).[1][28] In 1975 while
en route to join Hillary in the village of [Phaphlu](/wiki/Phaphlu "Phaphlu"),
where he was helping to build a hospital, Louise and Belinda were killed in a
plane crash near [Kathmandu](/wiki/Kathmandu "Kathmandu") airport shortly
after take-off.[7] In 1989 he married June Mulgrew, the widow of his close
friend [Peter Mulgrew](/wiki/Peter_Mulgrew "Peter Mulgrew"), who died on [Air
New Zealand Flight 901](/wiki/Air_New_Zealand_Flight_901 "Air New Zealand
Flight 901") in 1979.[8][81]

His son [Peter Hillary](/wiki/Peter_Hillary "Peter Hillary") also became a
climber, summiting Everest in 1990. In May 2002 Peter climbed Everest as part
of a 50th anniversary celebration; [Jamling Tenzing
Norgay](/wiki/Jamling_Tenzing_Norgay "Jamling Tenzing Norgay") (son of Tenzing
who had died in 1986) was also part of the expedition.[82]

Hillary's home for most of his life was a property on Remuera Road in Auckland
City,[83] where he enjoyed reading adventure and science fiction novels in his
retirement.[83] He also built a [bach](/wiki/Bach_\(New_Zealand\) "Bach \(New
Zealand\)") at Whites Beach,[84] one of Auckland's west coast beaches in the
former [Waitakere City](/wiki/Waitakere_City "Waitakere City"), between
[Anawhata](/wiki/Anawhata "Anawhata") and North [Piha](/wiki/Piha
"Piha");[85][86] a friend called it Hillary's place of solace, where he could
escape media attention.[84]

The Hillary family has had a connection with the west coast of Auckland since
1925, when Louise's father built a bach at Anawhata.[87] The family donated
land at Whites Beach that is now crossed by trampers on the Hillary Trail,
named for Edmund.[88] Hillary said of the area: "That is the thing that
international travel brings home to me – it's always good to be going home.
This is the only place I want to live in; this is the place I want to see out
my days."[89]

### Philanthropy

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Edmund_Hillary_by_Kubik_2004.jpg/170px-
Edmund_Hillary_by_Kubik_2004.jpg)](/wiki/File:Edmund_Hillary_by_Kubik_2004.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Edmund_Hillary_by_Kubik_2004.jpg "Enlarge")

Hillary in [Warsaw](/wiki/Warsaw "Warsaw") in 2004, wearing his [Commander's
Cross of the Order of Merit](/wiki/Order_of_Merit_of_the_Republic_of_Poland
"Order of Merit of the Republic of Poland")

Following his ascent of Everest he devoted himself to assisting the [Sherpa
people](/wiki/Sherpa_people "Sherpa people") of Nepal through the [Himalayan
Trust](/wiki/Himalayan_Trust "Himalayan Trust"), which he established in
1960[90] and led until his death in 2008. His efforts are credited with the
construction of many schools and hospitals in this remote region of the
[Himalayas](/wiki/Himalayas "Himalayas"). He was the Honorary President of the
[American Himalayan Foundation](/wiki/American_Himalayan_Foundation "American
Himalayan Foundation"), a United States non-profit body that helps improve the
ecology and living conditions in the Himalayas. He was also the Honorary
President of [Mountain Wilderness](/wiki/Mountain_Wilderness "Mountain
Wilderness"), an international NGO dedicated to the worldwide protection of
mountains.[91]

### Political involvement

Hillary took part in the [1975 New Zealand general
election](/wiki/New_Zealand_general_election,_1975 "New Zealand general
election, 1975"), as a member of the "[Citizens for
Rowling](/wiki/Citizens_for_Rowling "Citizens for Rowling")" campaign. His
involvement in this campaign was seen as precluding his nomination as
Governor-General;[92] the position was offered to [Keith
Holyoake](/wiki/Keith_Holyoake "Keith Holyoake") in 1977. In 1985, Hillary was
appointed New Zealand [High Commissioner to
India](/wiki/List_of_High_Commissioners_from_New_Zealand_to_India "List of
High Commissioners from New Zealand to India") (concurrently High Commissioner
to [Bangladesh](/wiki/Bangladesh "Bangladesh") and Ambassador to
[Nepal](/wiki/Nepal "Nepal")) and spent four and a half years based in [New
Delhi](/wiki/New_Delhi "New Delhi").[93]

In 1975, Hillary served as a vice president for the [Abortion Law Reform
Association of New
Zealand](/wiki/Abortion_Law_Reform_Association_of_New_Zealand "Abortion Law
Reform Association of New Zealand"),[94] a national [pro-choice](/wiki/Pro-
choice "Pro-choice") advocacy group.[95] He was also a patron of REPEAL, an
organization seeking repeal of the restrictive [Contraception, Sterilisation,
and Abortion Act
1977](/wiki/Contraception,_Sterilisation,_and_Abortion_Act_1977
"Contraception, Sterilisation, and Abortion Act 1977").[94]

## Death

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Edmund_Hillary_State_Funeral.jpg/220px-
Edmund_Hillary_State_Funeral.jpg)](/wiki/File:Edmund_Hillary_State_Funeral.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Edmund_Hillary_State_Funeral.jpg "Enlarge")

People draped in the [Flag of New Zealand](/wiki/Flag_of_New_Zealand "Flag of
New Zealand") as Hillary's [hearse](/wiki/Hearse "Hearse") passes

On 22 April 2007, while on a trip to [Kathmandu](/wiki/Kathmandu "Kathmandu"),
Hillary suffered a fall, and was hospitalised after returning to New
Zealand.[96] On 11 January 2008 he died of heart failure at [Auckland City
Hospital](/wiki/Auckland_City_Hospital "Auckland City Hospital").[97] Flags
were lowered to [half-mast](/wiki/Half-staff "Half-staff") on New Zealand
public buildings and at [Scott Base](/wiki/Scott_Base "Scott Base") in
Antarctica,[98] and Prime Minister [Helen Clark](/wiki/Helen_Clark "Helen
Clark") called Hillary's death a "profound loss to New Zealand".[99]

On 21 January, Hillary's casket was taken into [Holy Trinity
Cathedral](/wiki/Holy_Trinity_Cathedral,_Auckland "Holy Trinity Cathedral,
Auckland"), Auckland, to lie in state.[100] A [state
funeral](/wiki/State_funeral "State funeral") was held on 22 January
2008,[101] after which his body was [cremated](/wiki/Cremation "Cremation").
On 29 February 2008 most of his ashes were scattered in
[Auckland](/wiki/Auckland "Auckland")'s [Hauraki Gulf](/wiki/Hauraki_Gulf
"Hauraki Gulf") per his desire.[102] The remainder went to a Nepalese
monastery near Everest; a plan to scatter them on the summit was cancelled in
2010.[103]

### Posthumous tributes

In January 2008, Lukla Airport, in [Lukla](/wiki/Lukla "Lukla"), Nepal, was
renamed to [Tenzing–Hillary Airport](/wiki/Tenzing%E2%80%93Hillary_Airport
"Tenzing–Hillary Airport") in recognition of their promotion of its
construction.[104][105] On 2 April 2008, a service of thanksgiving in
Hillary's honour at [St George's Chapel at Windsor
Castle](/wiki/St_George%27s_Chapel_at_Windsor_Castle "St George's Chapel at
Windsor Castle") was attended by [Queen Elizabeth](/wiki/Elizabeth_II
"Elizabeth II"), New Zealand dignitaries including Prime Minister [Helen
Clark](/wiki/Helen_Clark "Helen Clark"), and members of Hillary's and Norgay's
families; [Gurkha](/wiki/Gurkha "Gurkha") soldiers from Nepal stood guard
outside the ceremony.[106][107] In October 2008, it was announced that future
rugby test matches between England and New Zealand would be played for the
[Hillary Shield](/wiki/Hillary_Shield "Hillary Shield").[108] In 2009 the
[Duke of Edinburgh's Award](/wiki/Duke_of_Edinburgh%27s_Award "Duke of
Edinburgh's Award") in New Zealand – formerly the Young New Zealanders'
Challenge – was renamed "The Duke of Edinburgh's Hillary Award".[109] On 5
November 2008, a commemorative set of five stamps was issued by [New Zealand
Post](/wiki/New_Zealand_Post "New Zealand Post").[110][111]

There have been many calls for lasting tributes to Hillary. The first major
public tribute has been by way of the "Summits for Ed" tribute tour organised
by the Sir Edmund Hillary Foundation.[112] This tribute tour went from Bluff
at the bottom of the South Island to Cape Reinga at the tip of the North
Island, visiting 39 towns and cities along the way. In each venue, school
children and members of the public were invited to join together to climb a
significant hill or site in their area to show their respect for Hillary. The
public were also invited to bring small rocks or pebbles that had special
significance to them, that would be included in a memorial to Hillary at the
base of Mt Ruapehu, in the grounds of the Sir Edmund Hillary Outdoor Pursuits
Centre. Funds donated during the tour are used by the foundation to sponsor
young New Zealanders on outdoor courses. Over 8,000 persons attended these
"Summit" climbs between March and May 2008.[113]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Mercer_Bay.jpg/220px-
Mercer_Bay.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mercer_Bay.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mercer_Bay.jpg "Enlarge")

View from the Hillary Trail

The tribute song "Hillary 88", by the New Zealand duo The Kiwis, is the
official world memorial song for Hillary, with the endorsement of Lady
Hillary.[114]

A four-day track in the Waitakere Ranges, along Auckland's west coast, is
named the Hillary Trail,[115] in honour of Hillary.[88] Hillary's father-in-
law, Jim Rose, who had built a bach at Anawhata in 1925, wrote in his 1982
history of Anawhata Beach, "My family look forward to the time when we will be
able to walk from [Huia](/wiki/Huia,_New_Zealand "Huia, New Zealand") to
[Muriwai](/wiki/Muriwai "Muriwai") on public walking tracks like the old-time
Maori could do".[87][116] Hillary loved the area, and had his own bach near
Anawhata. The track was opened on 11 January 2010, the second anniversary of
Hillary's death.[97][117] Rose Track, descending from Anawhata Road to Whites
Beach, is named after the Rose family.[89][118]

The South Ridge of Aoraki / Mount Cook, New Zealand's highest mountain, was
renamed Hillary Ridge on 18 August 2011. Hillary and three other climbers were
the first party to successfully climb the ridge in 1948.[119] In September
2013 the Government of Nepal proposed naming a 7,681 metres (25,200 ft)
mountain in Nepal [Hillary Peak](/wiki/Hillary_Peak "Hillary Peak") in his
honour.[120] After the _[New Horizons](/wiki/New_Horizons "New Horizons")_
mission discovered a mountain range on [Pluto](/wiki/Pluto "Pluto") on 14 July
2015, it was informally named [Hillary Montes](/wiki/Hillary_Montes "Hillary
Montes") (Hillary Mountains) by [NASA](/wiki/NASA "NASA").[121]

The [Sir Edmund Hillary Mountain Legacy
Medal](/wiki/Sir_Edmund_Hillary_Mountain_Legacy_Medal "Sir Edmund Hillary
Mountain Legacy Medal"), awarded by the Nepalese NGO Mountain Legacy "for
remarkable service in the conservation of culture and nature in mountainous
regions" was inaugurated in 2003, with the approval of Sir Edmund Hillary. A
[bronze](/wiki/Bronze "Bronze") bust of Hillary (circa 1953) by [Ophelia
Gordon Bell](/wiki/Ophelia_Gordon_Bell "Ophelia Gordon Bell") is in the [Te
Papa museum](/wiki/Museum_of_New_Zealand_Te_Papa_Tongarewa "Museum of New
Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa") in Wellington, New Zealand.[122] The Sir Edmund
Hillary Archive was added to the UNESCO [Memory of the world
archive](/wiki/Memory_of_the_World_Register_%E2%80%93_Asia_and_the_Pacific
"Memory of the World Register – Asia and the Pacific") in 2013,[123] it is
currently held by [Auckland War Memorial
Museum](/wiki/Auckland_War_Memorial_Museum "Auckland War Memorial
Museum").[124]
